details.title: Sequential diagnosis of processor array systems

p: Jun Zhao received the B.E. degree in Electronic Engineering from the University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China, in 1990; the M.S. degree in Electronic Engineering from Fudan University, Shanghai, China, in 1993; and the PhD in Computer Science from Texas A&M University, College Station, in 1999. In the fall of 1993, he joined the faculty of the Department of Electronic Engineering of Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai, China. From 1996 to 1997 he was a research assistant at Texas A&M University, then was a teaching assistant. He was a staff member in Lucent Technologies' FPGA Software Core Group. He is currently a Senior Software Engineer at Lattice Semiconductors, Bethlehem, PA. His research interests include CAT for VLSI, CAD for FPGA, and fault-tolerant computing.

Fred J. Meyer (S'86–M'91) is currently Assistant Professor of Electrical & Computer Engineering at Wichita State University. He was previously a faculty member at Northeastern University, and a Research Associate, Assistant Research Scientist, and Senior Lecturer of Computer Science at Texas A&M University, College Station. Before that he was a consultant for networks and training with Caelum Inc., Riverview FL, and was with the United States Air Force. He received the B.Sc. degree in Computer Systems Engineering from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, in 1984 and the Ph.D. degree from the Electrical & Computer Engineering Department of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, in 1991. His dissertation was on fault-tolerant distributed algorithms and distributed system testing. He has served as the Publicity Chair for the 1997 and 1998 IEEE International Workshops on Memory Technology, Design, and Testing. He served as Program co-Chair for the 2002 IEEE International Symposium on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI Systems and General co-Chair for the 2003 edition. He served as Guest co-Editor for the 1999 IEEE Design & Test of Computers theme issue on DRAM Architecture and Testing and the 2004 Elsevier Journal of System Architecture special issue on Design and Test of Systems on a Chip. He has served as an Associate Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Computers. His research interests include yield modeling and assessment, fault-tolerant architectures and nanocomputing, and digital design and test. He is a member of the IEEE Societies on Computers and Reliability.

Nohpill Park received the B.S. degree in 1987, and the M.S. degree in Computer Science in 1989, both from Seoul National University, Seoul, Korea. He received his Ph.D. in 1997 from the Department of Computer Science of Texas A&M University, where he was working as a research assistant in 1996, and as a research associate in 1997. He is currently an assistant professor in the Computer Science Department at Oklahoma State University since 1999. His research interests include computer architecture, defect and fault tolerant systems, testing and quality assurance of digital systems, parallel and distributed computer systems, multichip module systems, programmable digital systems, and system on chip.

Fabrizio Lombardi graduated in 1977 from the University of Essex (U.K.) with a B.Sc. (Hons.) in Electronic Engineering. In 1977 he joined the Microwave Research Unit at University College London, where he received the Master in Microwaves and Modern Optics (1978), the Diploma in Microwave Engineering (1978), and the Ph.D. from the University of London (1982). He is currently the holder of the International Test Conference (ITC) Endowed Professorship at Northeastern University, Boston. Prior to this, he was a faculty member at Texas Tech University, the University of Colorado-Boulder, and Texas A&M University. He has received many professional awards: the Visiting Fellowship at the British Columbia Advanced System Institute, University of Victoria, Canada (1988), twice the TEES Research Fellowship (1991–1992, 1997–1998), the Halliburton Professorship (1995) and and an International Research Award from the Ministry of Science and Education of Japan (1993–1999). Dr. Lombardi was the recipient of the 1985/86 Research Initiation Award from the IEEE/Engineering Foundation, a Silver Quill Award from Motorola-Austin (1996) and a Distinguished Visitor of the IEEE Computer Society for the period 1990–93. Dr. Lombardi was an Associate Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Computers (1996–2000). Currently he is the Associate Editor-in-Chief of IEEE Transactions on Computers, and Associate Editor of the IEEE Design and Test Magazine. Dr. Lombardi has been involved in organizing many international symposia, conferences, and workshops sponsored by organizations such as NATO and IEEE, as well as guest editor in archival journals and magazines such as the IEEE Transactions on Computers, IEEE Micro Magazine, and IEEE Design & Test Magazine. His research interests are testing and design of digital systems, configurable computing, defect tolerance, and CAD VLSI. He has extensively published in these areas, and edited six books.

details.abstract: We examine the diagnosis of processor array systems formed as two-dimensional arrays, with boundaries, and either four or eight neighbors for each interior processor. We employ a parallel test schedule. Neighboring processors test each other, and report the results. Our diagnostic objective is to find a fault-free processor or set of processors. The system may then be sequentially diagnosed by repairing those processors tested faulty according to the identified fault-free set, or a job may be run on the identified fault-free processors. We establish an upper bound on the maximum number of faults which can be sustained without invalidating the test results under worst case conditions. We give test schedules and diagnostic algorithms which meet the upper bound as far as the highest order term. We compare these near optimal diagnostic algorithms to alternative algorithms, both new and already in the literature, and against an upper bound ideal case algorithm, which is not necessarily practically realizable. For eight-way array systems with N processors, an ideal algorithm has diagnosability 3N/sup 2/3/-2N/sup 1/2/ plus lower-order terms. No algorithm exists which can exceed this. We give an algorithm which starts with tests on diagonally connected processors, and which achieves approximately this diagnosability. So the given algorithm is optimal to within the two most significant terms of the maximum diagnosability. Similarly, for four-way array systems with N processors, no algorithm can have diagnosability exceeding 3N/sup 2/3//2/sup 1/3/-2N/sup 1/2/ plus lower-order terms. And we give an algorithm which begins with tests arranged in a zigzag pattern, one consisting of pairing nodes for tests in two different directions in two consecutive test stages; this algorithm achieves diagnosability (3/2)(5/2)/sup 1/3/N/sup 2/3/-(5/4)N/sup 1/2/ plus lower-order terms, which is about 0.85 of the upper bound due to an ideal algorithm.

context.text: However, to maintain consistency with [1], we will seek to identify at least one fault-free processor.
Reference [1] proposed an algorithm to reach this goal, but the algorithm was only applied to the case in Fig. 1(b), the 8-way array.
Moreover, [1] does the diagnosis based on the cluster level instead of the single processor level.
Using clusters in [1] also causes many fault-free processors to be wrongly marked as suspect, and included in the perimeter which separates the apparent Fault-Free Sets of processors.
The algorithm in [1] divides the processors into 3 × 3 blocks.
For the algorithm in [1], we count 3 × 3 blocks.
Also, we know that our proposed algorithm's diagnosability is much better than [1], by about a factor of 2.1, and reaches that of the ideal to the first 2 significant terms.
Fig. 17 plots the diagnosability for an 8-way array system with various test schedules, including [1].
4-way array systems are not treated in [1].
After these tests, we view the array as composed of a number of 2 × 2 blocks cf. the 3 × 3 blocks in [1].
Compare this to the monolithic 3 × 3 blocks in [1].
In the test procedure, each (2 × 2) block of [1] functions as a single processor in an ideal algorithm, so a diamond is also the optimal geometric form for the modified [1] in 4-way array systems.
We note that the result on the 4-way array system for our modified method of [1] is even superior to the same method on an 8-way array system.
Fig. 20 gives the diagnosability for an ideal algorithm, our adaptation of the algorithm in [1], and our proposed algorithms.
When the system size is large, the diagnosability of our proposed algorithm is much better than [1] by a factor of about 2.1 for 8-way arrays.

references.title: A polynomial time algorithm for fault diagnosability

context.text: Under the PMC model, there are polynomial time algorithms for determining the diagnosability, \$t\$ [20]; and polynomial algorithms for performing fault diagnosis [4].

[20] proposed a \$O(\vert E\vert n^{1.5})\$ algorithm (\$\vert E\vert\$ is the number of tests, \$n\$ is the number of processors) to solve the diagnosability problem under the PMC model, and [17] improved the efficiency of the \$t\$-diagnosability algorithm to \$O(nt^{2.5})\$. [18] also showed that finding the diagnosability of a repairable system is co-\${\cal NP}\$-complete.
Therefore, if a \$t\$-diagnosability algorithm [20] is employed, the system can only tolerate 2 faulty processors, no matter the system size.
